text: in Copenhagen representatives of
developing countries threatened to walk
out of the climate talks they say richer
nations are not doing enough to cut
greenhouse gas emissions or offering
enough money to poor countries to help
them cope with climate change we talked
with Libby Rosenthal who is in
Copenhagen after a visit to Bolivia
which is one of the countries that feels
economically powerless to manage climate
change the problem in Bolivia is that
much of La Paz and Altos water supply
these are the two big endian cities
depends on glaciers and those glaciers
are melting because of climate change
and the problem for the cities of course
is that they don't have water and as the
Bolivian see it these glaciers are
melting because of emissions from richer
more developed countries and so the
richer more developed countries should
be paying them and helping them deal
with the effects of climate change that
are so severe on the ground there and
how optimistic is Bolivia for example or
even other poorer countries that they're
going to get money at all to deal with
these problems oh well they're very very
worried as we saw today at the meetings
here they worry very much that they're
going to be left without any assistance
and as they say they are feeling the
effects of a problem that they didn't
create and so they expect to be paid
with money and with health in the way of
technology as well
